Hi Colin, I know a lot about the NEON system since I was the external 
exam=
iner on Benjamin Inden's dissertation (which was on NEON).  I am 
not sure =
though where publications on it are freely available.  
Hopefully he will p=
rovide his publication to Derek.

NEON is a fairly complicated indirect enc=
oding that collapses into 
something very similar to regular NEAT if some p=
arts of it are 
removed.  Many of the experiments are in fact in effect exp=
eriments 
with NEAT, and some are interesting because they extensively stud=
y 
the effects of specific aspects of NEAT like speciation.  

However, the=
 indirect encoding part is more difficult to understand 
or interpret, and =
I am guessing that Benjamin Inden will continue to 
modify his ideas for in=
direct encoding in NEON over time.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Col=
in Green" <locster01@...> wrote:
>
> Hi, Does anyone know anything about th=
is:
> 
> "Stepwise Transition from Direct Encoding to Artificial Ontogeny i=
n
> Neuroevolution"
> http://www.springerlink.com/content/52272p730177r470/=

> 
> ------------------
> Benjamin Inden
> (1)  	Max Planck Institute for =
Mathematics in the Sciences,
> 
> Abstract
> There is a gap between neuroev=
olution systems employing artificial
> ontogeny and those being able to sol=
ve difficult control tasks. The
> NEON system builds on ideas of the well k=
nown NEAT neuroevolution
> system to make possible a stepwise transition fr=
om a direct encoding
> to complex genetic architectures using developmental=
 processes.
> ------------------
> 
> 
> Colin.
